Nanostructured CeO2 based catalysts were employed as tools to shed light on the mechanism of the acetone synthesis from ethanol. The oxides were characterized using HRTEM, EPR, and other techniques. Rates of ethanol consumption and products formation were measured at differential conditions. The catalysts prepared employing Ce(NO3)3 generate nanocubes, whereas when (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 is used, nanopolyhedral particles are synthesised. The later forms O vacancies more easily. This property enhances when Ag is added to the nanopolyhedral catalyst. The correlation between the catalytic behaviour and the nanocatalysts`s physicochemical properties showed that O vacancies participate as Brønsted basic sites in the acetaldehyde synthesis and that the easier the O vacancies generation, the higher the rate of the acetone synthesis is. The O abstraction from the CeO2 lattice by acetaldehyde (Mars and Van Krevelen mechanism) is the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from ethanol, showing that this synthesis exhibits a relevant redox characteristic. Keywords Ethanol Acetaldehyde Mars and Van Krevelen mechanism CeO2 Acetone 1 Introduction Acetone is an important chemical widely used in the syntheses of drugs and polymers. Its largest application is the manufacture of acetone cyanohydrin (ACH), which is the precursor of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and methacrylic acid. This ketone is also usually employed in the production of bisphenol-A (BPA), polycarbonate, and in the syntheses of many other chemicals, for instance, methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK), isophorone and diacetone alcohol/hexylene glycol, and others [1]. Nowadays, acetone is mainly produced by the Cumene process from benzene and propylene. This synthesis generates acetone and phenol (0.62 ton of this ketone per ton of phenol). Thus, the acetone and phenol production via the Cumene process depends on the market conditions of both products. Ethanol, used as a fuel additive and gasoline substitute, is produced from sugarcane and corn. This alcohol is also a very special platform molecule. Many drop-in chemicals can be synthetised in one-pot processes from ethanol employing multifunctional catalysts [2]. According to the literature, the acetone synthesis from ethanol is technically feasible [3–8]. This synthesis also generates CO2 and H2 (eq. 1), which can both further react to generate CH4, DME, methanol, etc. Many different catalytic systems have been employed in this synthesis, for example ZnO-CaO [3], Fe2O3-ZnO [4], CuO/CeO2 [8], AgCeO2 [9], ZnxZryOz [10], Cu/ZnO/Al2O3+ZrO2 [11] and others. Propene and isobutene are very important chemicals which can be synthesised in one step from ethanol. Acetone is the main intermediate of both syntheses. In addition, the generation of acetone from ethanol is one of the steps of the cascade systems employed in the generation of these olefins. On the one hand, the propene synthesis from ethanol can be described as following: firstly, acetone is generated from ethanol; then, this ketone is hydrogenated to isopropanol; finally, propene is synthetized by the dehydration of the C3 alcohol. On the other hand, the isobutene synthesis can be depicted according the following steps: firstly, acetone is generated from ethanol; next, this ketone condenses (aldol condensation) forming the diacetone alcohol; then, this alcohol dehydrates to mesityl oxide which decomposes generating isobutene and acetaldehyde; finally, the aldehyde is oxidised by H2O to acetone and CO2 [12,13]. It is worth mentioning from the thermodynamic point of view, the main reaction between ethanol and water is the ethanol reforming. On the other hand, the generation isobutene, propene and acetone from the same reagents is related to the kinetic phenomenon [2]. (1) 2 CH3CH2OH + H2O → CH3COCH3 + CO2 + 4 H2 The first studies related to the acetone synthesis from ethanol were undertaken by the Tanabe group [3,5]. Employing the ZnFe2O4 and ZnO-CaO catalysts, they proposed that acetaldehyde is obtained by the dehydrogenation of ethanol. After that, this aldehyde is oxidized by superficial hydroxyl species generating acetate species, which then condense, producing acetone. They also suggested that the acetaldehyde oxidation is the rate limiting step (rls) of the acetone synthesis. Iwamoto et al. [14] studying the propene synthesis from ethanol employing Sc/In2O3, also proposed this same mechanism for the acetone generation. Afterwards, Hayashi et al. [15] suggested another mechanism employing Y2O3-CeO2, which can be described as following: firstly, acetaldehyde condenses leading to ethyl acetate; then, the ester is hydrolyzed to ethanol and acetate species; finally, the latter condenses and generates acetone. Recently, Gonzalez et al. [16] employing Cu/ZrO2/Al2O3 have proposed almost the same mechanism. In the late 1980s, Murthy et al. [4] employing the Fe-based catalyst, proposed the following mechanism: firstly, ethanol is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde; next, this aldehyde undergoes an aldol condensation generating acetaldol (3-hydroxybutyraldehyde); then, this compound is dehydrogenated and decomposed generating acetic acid and acetaldehyde or acetone and formic acid; finally, the acetic acid is ketonized to acetone. Nishiguchi et al. [8], employing CuO/CeO2, also proposed the acetaldehyde condensation generating acetaldol. In this case, it was suggested that acetaldol is oxidized and decomposed producing acetone, CO2 and H2. The oxidant agent is the O of the CeO2 lattice. Recently, Liu et al. [17] studying the isobutene synthesis from ethanol employing the CrxZnyZrzOn catalyst have proposed that the generation of acetone, one of the intermediate specie of this synthesis, also occurs via the acetaldol decomposition. Idriss & Seebauer [6] and Yee et al. [18] suggested two different mechanisms according to the catalyst composition. In the presence of noble metals such as Pd, the acetyl species are synthetized from acetaldehyde, which then condenses generating acetone. When CeO2 is employed, firstly, acetaldehyde is generated from ethanol; then, this aldehyde is oxidized to acetate species by the O of the oxide surface; finally, the ketonization of the acetate species occurs. De Lima et al. [9], Silva-Calpa et al. [10] and Rodrigues et al. [11] employing AgCeO2, ZnxZryOz and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3+ZrO2, respectively, proposed the following mechanism: firstly, ethanol is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde; next, this aldehyde is oxidized to acetate species by the O of the oxide lattice, generating vacancies; then, H2O dissociates on the vacancies and reoxidises the catalyst surface generating H2; finally, acetate species condenses and produces acetone and CO2. It is worth stressing that the oxidation of acetaldehyde to acetate species follows the Mars and Van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism, in which the O vacancy formation is the slowest step, i.e., the rate-limiting step (rls). Recently, Rorrer et al. [19] analysing the isobutene synthesis from ethanol employing ZnxZryOz have proposed a mechanism similar to the one mentioned last. As can be observed (Scheme 1 ), most of these mechanisms show the same first and last steps. The disagreement which exists among the authors is related to the acetate species or acetic acid generation from acetaldehyde. Without question, any mechanism depends on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. Most of the proposed mechanisms are related to the acid and basic properties of the catalysts. In the case of systems which show redox properties, the MvK mechanism might be the most suitable one. Our group analysed the catalytic behaviour of CeO2 doped (0.5 wt%) with some metals (Ni, Fe, Zn, Mn, Nb, Mo, Zr, Ag, Cu e Co) in the acetone synthesis from ethanol. The Ag catalyst showed the best performance (Fig. S1). The CeO2 oxide can be synthetised according to the following morphologies: thin films, nanocubes, nanorods, nanospheres and nanooctahedron [20–23]. It is known that changing the oxides’ morphologies change the surface crystallographic planes as well. Moreover, the type of surface plane determine the energy related to the O vacancy surface formation [24–26]. Thus, when the O vacancy formation is relevant (redox mechanism), the CeO2 morphology might directly impacts the catalytic activity. According to Chang et al. [27], adding Ag to the nanostructured CeO2 oxide, the reducibility of this oxide is improved, i.e., it is easier to generate O vacancies. They observed that Ag improve the reduction of the CeO2 surface promoting the CO oxidation. Oxides can be very interesting and challenging catalysts. Their physicochemical properties and, consequently, the catalytic behaviour can be drastically changed or tunned using different preparation procedures. Adding dopants or single atoms to the oxide’s surfaces and synthetising oxides with specific morphologies are examples of these methodologies. Oxides can show acid, basic, redox and others properties, which make them multifunctional catalysts capable to promote cascade reactions [28]. Taking this piece of information into account, this work only employs oxides as catalysts. Therefore, the aim of this work is to describe the role of the O vacancies in acetone synthesis from ethanol in order to support the MvK mechanism as one of the steps of the acetone synthesis from ethanol. Two different morphologies of nano CeO2 catalysts, being one of them doped with Ag, are employed. The ethanol-TPD, UV–vis spectroscopy, CO2-TPD, EPR, Raman spectroscopy and also HRTEM characterizations are used in order to uphold the proposed mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The nanocatalysts were synthesised by the hydrothermal method [27]. Firstly, the NaOH solution (CNaOH =6 mol L−1) was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3.6H2O or (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 and AgNO3 under continuous stirring at room temperature. The concentration of the Ce precursors in the solutions was 0.06 mol L−1. The amount of AgNO3 added to the (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 solution was calculated to reach 0.02 wt.% of Ag in the final oxide. After precipitation, the suspension was stirred for 30 min and then transferred to a 200 mL stainless-steel vessel autoclave with an internal Teflon bottle. The system was heated at 180 °C for 24 h under autogenous pressure. After that, the solid was washed with distilled water up to neutral pH, centrifuged, dried at 80 °C overnight, and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h (10 °C min−1) under air flow (30 mL min−1). The catalyst obtained employing Ce(NO3)3 was named CeO2(ncb), while the ones synthetised with (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 as CeO2(npl) and AgCeO2(npl). 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 BET analysis The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific area of the catalysts was measured by N2 adsorption at −196 °C employing a Micromeritics ASAP 2420. The samples were pretreated at 100 °C for 24 h, and then submitted to vacuum at 350 °C for 2 h. 2.2.2 CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) The CO2 temperature-programmed desorption was carried out using a TPR/TPD Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The adsorption of CO2 was performed at room temperature for 1 h (20 mL min−1). The measurements were conducted at 20 °C min−1, under He flow (50 mLmin−1), up to 450 °C. In order to classify basic sites as weak, medium and strong strength, the TPD profiles were decomposed in Gaussian curves. The weak basic sites are assigned to a curve which exhibits a maximum at a temperature lower than 127 °C, medium basic sites between 127 °C and 307 °C, and strong basic sites above 307 °C. The samples were pretreated according the following procedure: firstly, the sample was dried at 130 °C under inert flow for 30 min; after that, reduced under 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL min−1) at 450 °C for 1 h; then, purged with N2 and oxidized for 30 min with synthetic air at the same temperature; finally, the catalyst was cooled to ambient temperature under inert gas flow. The pretreatment was carried out to remove carbonate species from the catalysts surface. 2.2.3 Isopropanol conversion The acidity and basicity of the CeO2 nanocatalysts were analysed employing the isopropanol conversion model reaction. A fixed-bed reactor monitored online by a gas chromatograph with flame ionization (FID) and thermal conductivity (TCD) detectors were employed. The catalysts were pretreated according the procedure described for the CO2-TPD. The tests were carried out at 200 °C, 1 atm and under differential conditions (∼10 % conversion). The isopropanol vapours were generated by passing N2 through a saturator at 10 °C. 2.2.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The size and the morphology of the CeO2 nanoparticles were investigated by transmission electron microscopy using a Tecnai G2-F20 (FEI/ThermoFisher) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. High-resolution (HRTEM) images were obtained in a200 kV 2.100 F equipment (JEOL). The samples were previously dispersed in isopropanol, sonicated for 15 min, and then supported on a holey carbon-coated copper grid (#200) for TEM analysis. 2.2.5 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were collected at ambient temperature employing a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR800 UV spectrometer, equipped with a CCD detector at a −70 °C, with excitation by 632.8 nm from a He-Ne laser and the laser power limited to 20 mW. The scanning region was ranged from 100 to 1000 cm−1. The spectra were normalized to the highest energy intensity (465 cm−1). The samples were analysed without thermal treatment. 2.2.6 Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance (UV–vis) The ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra were collected employing a Varian Cary 500 spectrophotometer, at the range of 200−800 nm. The BaSO4 powder was used as a reference. The samples were analysed without thermal treatment. These spectra were employed to calculate the band gap values. Direct and indirect band gaps are estimated from Tauc plots [29,30]. The Urbach energy is estimated from the exponential fitting of the data below the bandgap [31]. 2.2.7 Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) Electron paramagnetic resonance spectra were collected using a Bruker ESP 300E spectrometer operating in the X-band (9.7 GHz). The following pre-treatment was employed: firstly, the catalysts were dried at 130 °C under He flow for 30 min; next, reduced under 20 % H2/Ar at 450 °C (10 °C min−1) for 1 h; finally, purged and cooled to ambient temperature under Ar flow. The spectra were collected at room temperature using a microwave power, amplitude modulation and frequency modulation of 20 mW, 5 G and 100 kHz, respectively. Room temperature ferromagnetism in CeO2 has been frequently associated to oxygen vacancies. EPR spectral areas are proportional to the amount of magnetic material, related to the amount of oxygen vacancies and can be calculated as Ym.(ΔH)2 where Ym and ΔH are intensity and linewidth of derivative curve, respectively [32]. Spectral deconvolutions were performed with derivatives of Lorentzian lines. 2.2.8 H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The H2 temperature-programmed reduction experiments were performed after the same pretreatment employed in the case of the CO2-TPD and using a TPR/TPD Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The H2-TPR was carried out under 10 % H2/N2 flow (30 mL min−1) and the temperature was increased up to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °Cmin−1. 2.2.9 Ethanol temperature programmed desorption (ethanol-TPD) Ethanol temperature-programmed desorption was performed using a micro-reactor system coupled to a Pfeiffer Omni Star mass spectrometer. The samples were pretreated following the same steps of CO2-TPD. After that, the ethanol adsorption was conducted at 50 °C for 1 h. Ethanol vapours were obtained by passing He (20 mL min−1) through a saturator with ethanol at 30 °C. The desorption was carry out employing a He flow (80 mL min−1) at 20 °C min−1 from 50 °C to 450 °C and remaining at 450 °C for 30 min. The fragments m/z = 2 (H2), 44 (CO2), 18 (H2O), 26 (ethylene), 29 (acetaldehyde), 31 (ethanol), 39 (propene) and 43 (acetone) were monitored during the analyses. The intensities of these fragments were mathematically treated in order to eliminate contributions from more than one species. When a peak of the m/e=A spectrum is related to more than one compound (C and D), another m/e=B fragment, assigned only to C should be identified. The ratio between m/e=B and m/e=A peaks intensities is calculated. Considering this ratio, it is possible to calculate the C contribution in the m/e=A spectrum. Subtracting this contribution from m/e=A spectrum the signal related to D is obtained. 2.2.10 Chemical analysis The Ag content was determined using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), Horiba Scientific, Ultima 2. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were performed using a conventional system with a fixed bed reactor at 1 atm. The N2:H2O:C2H5OH = 91:8:1 vol.% mixture employed was generated by ethanol and H2O vapours by passing N2 through two saturators, one at 5 °C and another at 52 °C, respectively. The CeO2 based catalysts were pretreated according to the following steps: firstly, the sample was dried at 130 °C for 30 min under N2 flow (90 mL min−1); next, reduced under 10 % H2/N2 flow (100 mL min−1) at 450 °C for 1 h; finally, cooled at inert atmosphere up to the temperature of the catalytic test. The performance of the catalysts analyzed at the same contact time was obtained at the following experimental conditions: flow rate, catalyst mass and reaction temperature were 50 mL min−1, 50 mg and 400 °C, respectively. The reaction rates were measured under differential conditions (conversion < 10 %) at 400 °C. The reaction products were analysed during 16 h on stream by gas chromatography using a CG Agilent 6890 equipped with two detectors (thermal conductivity and flame ionization), methanator and a Porapak-Q/60 ft column. The product’s selectivity is defined by the ratio between the number of the carbon moles consumed to synthesise a product to the total number of carbon moles consumed. Considering the acetone synthesis reaction (eq. 1), 75 % is the highest selectivity to acetone which can be reached. The ethanol conversion is defined as the ratio of the moles of ethanol consumed to the moles of ethanol in the reagent mixture. The selectivities and conversions values were calculated employing the data average obtained between 10 and 14 h in time on stream. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 exhibits the catalytic behaviour of the prepared catalysts employing the same experimental conditions. The second step of the acetone synthesis is related to the generation of this ketone from acetaldehyde (see introduction). According to the literature, many mechanisms have been suggested for this reaction. At this point, the redox mechanism will be selected. Then, the correlation between the acetone generation rates and the redox properties of the catalyst will be analysed in order to verify if this mechanism is able to describe the acetone generation from acetaldehyde. The ethanol-TPD on AgCeO2(npl) is depicted in Fig. 6 , which shows H2, CO2, H2O, ethylene, acetaldehyde, ethanol and acetone spectra. Ethanol, H2O and acetaldehyde desorption occur at the same temperature (170 °C). These data suggest that acetaldehyde is generated by the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol due to the simultaneous water synthesis. This reaction reduces the catalyst, i.e., generates O vacancies [9]. Increasing the temperature, ethylene and H2O are synthesised via the ethanol dehydration. Indeed, ethylene, H2O and H2 show bands with maxima around 298 °C. It can be suggested that H2O dissociates on the O vacancies of the catalyst generating H2 and oxidizing the catalyst [50]. At this same temperature (298 °C), the acetone peak emerges which might be formed by the acetaldehyde oxidation followed by the acetate condensation. At higher temperatures, the CO2 a by-product of the acetone synthesis is observed. The ethanol-TPD shows that the generation of acetaldehyde from ethanol is the first step of this acetone synthesis, which is in line with the data in Table 1 and previous works [9,10]. Therefore, the rate of ethanol consumption in this cascade reaction depends on the catalyst behaviour in the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. The mechanism of the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol can be described as following: firstly, ethoxide is formed by the H abstraction from the ethanol OH; next, the aldehyde is generated by the α-H abstraction from the ethoxide species by strong basic sites; then, H2O is desorbed forming an O vacancy on the catalyst surface. The α-H abstraction step is identified as the rate limiting step (rls) of the ethanol oxidative dehydrogenation [51,52]. According to the literature [51,52], strong basic sites are relevant for the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. Tables 1 and 2 show that when adding Ag to CeO2(npl), the number of these sites decreases, whereas the acetaldehyde synthesis rate increases. Thus, these sites might promote the dehydrogenation reaction. However, they are not the most important species. Indeed, it is well known that O vacancies are strong basic sites [53]. Recently, Chagas et al. [28] have proposed that O vacancies behave as strong Brønsted basic sites in the rls of the ethanol dehydrogenation. Indeed, the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction shows the same rls than the ethanol dehydrogenation. It can be observed that the higher the vacancies number (reduced, see the ranking), the higher the rate of acetaldehyde formation is (Table 1). Therefore, it can be suggested that O vacancies participate in the rls of the acetaldehyde generation. Moreover, when O vacancies are generated, cus species, which are acid sites, are also formed [28]. In addition, ethoxide species might adsorb on the cus sites. As a result, pairs of oxygen vacancies and cus species might be the sites where rls of the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction occurs. Taking ethanol-TPD (Fig. 6) results into account, it can be suggested that this ketone generation is the slowest step of this cascade synthesis as it is synthesised at the highest temperature (Scheme 2 ). Changing the morphology from nanocubic to nanopolyhedral and also adding Ag to the latter, the acetone generation rate increases (Table 1). There is also an increase in the tendency to generate vacancies. According to de Lima et al. [9], Silva-Calpa et al. [10] and Matheus et al. [12] this step can be described as following: firstly, acetaldehyde is oxidised to acetate species by the O of the oxide lattice generating O vacancies and cus species; then, these carboxilates condense and synthesise acetone and CO2; finally, H2O dissociates on the vacancies and reoxidizes the catalyst. Hence, acetate generation (acetaldehyde oxidation) might occurs by the MvK mechanism being H2O the oxidant agent. According to Kumar et al. [54] the acetate species condensation (ketonization) takes place on acid and basic sites being this reaction very fast at temperatures higher than 300 °C. Moreover, H2O dissociation is also a very fast step [9,16,50]. Thus, the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from acetaldehyde might be the aldehyde oxidation or acetate formation. According to McFarland et al. [55], the slowest step of the MvK oxidation is the oxygen abstraction from the oxide lattice and not the insertion of O in the molecules to be oxidized. As a consequence, the catalyst which generates vacancies more easily should be the one which is the most active for the acetate formation. These results are in line with the experimental results described above (Table 1). Indeed, the easier the vacancies generation on the CeO2 based catalysts is, the higher the acetone synthesis rate will be. This result suggests that the MvK mechanism hypothesis might be correct. The O abstraction from the oxide lattice is the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from acetaldehyde, which is the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from ethanol. Hence, it can be highlighted the relevance of the MvK mechanism in this reaction system. The rate of ethanol consumption and acetaldehyde generation increases as more O vacancies are generated. This mechanism exhibits that H (oxidative dehydrogenation) and also acetaldehyde are able to promote the generation of O vacancy, being the O abstraction much easier for the former (see Fig. 6). Most of the propositions related to the acetone synthesis mechanism are based on the acid and basic properties of the catalysts (see introduction). Comparing the acidity and basicity data (Table 2) of the CeO2 based catalysts with their acetone generation rates (Table 1), it can be inferred that there is no correlation between these properties and the catalytic behaviour. The main characteristic of the MvK mechanism is the use of the O from the oxide lattice (catalyst) as oxidant agent of intermediates species. Indeed, the correlation between the facility to provide O from the CeO2 lattice (be reduced) and the catalytic behaviour of this oxides in the acetone synthesis from ethanol shows the relevance of the MvK mechanism for this reaction system. The three prepared catalysts generate ethylene as a by-product of the acetone synthesis from ethanol. The competition between dehydrogenation and dehydration of ethanol occurs in many systems in which ethanol are employed as feedstock. Considering that these catalysts do not show strong acid sites and according to Di Cosimo et al. [51], ethylene can be synthesised employing pairs of strong basic and acid sites. On the one hand, it can be inferred that there is a linear correlation between the ethylene formation rate (Table 1) and the number of strong basic sites obtained by the CO2-TPD (Table 2). On the other hand, Table 1 shows that the Ag promoted catalyst generates less ethylene than CeO2(npl) despite its higher O vacancies concentration (which are also strong basic sites). Hence, it can be suggested that O vacancies are mainly associated with the acetone synthesis process and the strong basic sites (CO2-TPD) to ethanol dehydration. Two different Ce precursors, Ce(NO3)3 or (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6, were employed in the CeO2 synthesis. The (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 aqueous solution shows a stable 12-coordinate icosahedron complex in which the six NO3− ligands are bounded to Ce4+ in its chelate mode by two oxygen atoms (Ce(NO3)6 2-), whereas Ce(NO3)3 in aqueous solution forms Ce3+. Thus, the chemical behaviour of these species during preparation might be distinct. Accordingly, these two cerium precursors generate oxides with different morphology, physicochemical properties and reactivity [44]. Branda et al. [56] used DFT to study the interaction of Ag, Au, and Cu atoms on the CeO2 (111) surface. They verified that Ag ions prefer 3-fold symmetry positions with an adsorption energy of -1.0 eV and a Bader net charge of +0.56. They also suggest that the Ag atoms are adsorbed as ions distributed over the surface, forming a periodic array. In order to describe the AgCeO2 (npl) catalyst, the Urbach energy [57] was calculated employing the UV–vis spectra (Fig. S5). The CeO2(npl) and AgCeO2 (npl) values obtained were 0.13 and 0.09 eV, respectively. Taking the Branda et al. [56] DFT study into account, the slightly smaller Urbach energy obtained for the AgCeO2(npl) compared to CeO2(npl) can be associated with the Ag1+ ions adsorbed on the CeO2 surface which favour surface reordering. Moreover, it can be suggested that Ag1+ species on CeO2 show electrophilic character (Bader net charge). Thus, during the acetone synthesis and also TPR experiments the Ag1+ species favour the O exit, also an electrophilic species, from the surface lattice promoting the formation of oxygen vacancies [55]. The AgCeO2(npl) catalyst is a promising system for the acetone synthesis from ethanol as it shows not only high activity and selectivity to acetone and but also low selectivity to ethene. Moreover, the nanostructured CeO2 catalysts are very useful tools for showing the relevance of the O vacancies and the redox character of the acetone synthesis mechanism. 4 Conclusions Three nanostructured CeO2 based catalysts were synthesised employing two different Ce precursors and Ag as a dopant. In spite of being promising catalysts for the acetone synthesis from ethanol they were employed as tools to describe the mechanism of this reaction. The catalysts prepared employing (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 show nanopolyhedral particles whereas when Ce(NO3)3 is used nanocubes are synthesized. The former not only generate O vacancies more easily, but also exhibit a higher number of these species when reduced. Doping the nanopolyhedral oxide with Ag these properties are enhanced. The O vacancies participate as Brønsted basic sites in the rate limiting step of the ethanol oxidative dehydrogenation reaction, which is the first step of this cascade system. The O abstraction from the oxide lattice is the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from acetaldehyde, which is the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from ethanol. Indeed, the easier the vacancy generation, the higher the rate of the acetone synthesis is. This result is in line with the MvK mechanism, in which acetaldehyde abstracts O from CeO2 lattice forming acetate species and O vacancies. Considering the catalytic behaviour of these three catalysts, it can be proposed that the slowest step of the acetone synthesis from ethanol exhibits a relevant redox characteristic. The main characteristic of the MvK mechanism is the use of the O from the oxide lattice (catalyst) as an oxidant agent. The oxides were characterized using HRTEM, EPR, and other techniques. Rates of ethanol consumption and products formation were measured at differential conditions.
